abstract.p: Monogram craze includes embroidered tanks and baby T-shirts and liquid-filled squeeze bottles for initialing cocktails; photos (Pulse column) (M)

block.p: Ever since celebrities -- like Madonna and Reese Witherspoon started stamping their initials on sweatsuits and jeans, the stodgy practice of monogramming has become a born-again craze. At bars like the Breakers, in the famous hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., and Bungalow 8 in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, bartenders use nozzle-tip squeeze bottles filled with black raspberry honey and Chambord to monogram cocktails. Williams-Sonoma offers steak branders for searing initials on barbecued meats ($34.95 for double or triple initials at www.williams-sonoma.com). At Fred Segal in Los Angeles, Priorities, a company that specializes in hip monogramming, offers boy tanks and baby T's that can be monogrammed in several font styles and embroidery hues. ($58 to $62, also at www.prioritiesnyc.com). Kleinberg Sherrill makes handbags, including a $25,500 alligator bag with pavé diamond initials (at www.kleinbergsherrill.com). And at the Tracey Ross boutique in Los Angeles, anything can have initials for $15 -- an appropriate way for the current Me Generation to sign off.
